awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Early Elementary Reading Verification in Challenging Acoustic Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Young students who have difficulty in reading fluently can gain confidence by repeatedly reading story passages. Computer reading assessment can help improve student’s fluency while freeing up teacher to help students more efficiently. In previous projects, computer-based technologies have been shown to improve the reading ability of low performing readers in urban schools. Reading verification is a critical task, determining whether a student has correctly read the words on the page, or has mispronounced words, is stuck, or has jumped ahead or back. However, current systems that use automatic speech recognition (ASR) tend towards accepting incorrect pronunciations, instead of figuring out mistakes, and operate poorly when there is noise. This project addresses these issues by studying how to build a reliable computer system that can tell, in real-time, whether students are reading correctly within a noisy classroom, and make it available on many different types of computers. To allow other researchers to compare their studies, the project team will create and make available a dataset of reading examples recorded in noise through the Language Research Lab at the Center of Science and Industry (COSI) museum. By interacting with lab personnel, visitors will be educated on how speech recognition systems work as well as on how language science research is done. Thus, if this project is successful, significantly better computer-based reading assessment technologies will be developed, which will help many children read better, and the public will become better informed about reading, speech technologies and science in general. 

The approach investigated in this project abandons the need for full ASR technology, instead performing Reading Verification (RV) directly on the speech signal while jointly performing speech enhancement to focus on the child's speech. The elimination of ASR decoding technology permits creation of smaller verification models that can be deployed on devices or web browsers. Building on pilot work in mispronunciation detection and integration of phonetic information into speech enhancement, a new attention-based tracking approach is examined that directly models phenomena like partial word disfluencies, explores the difference between enhancement for child and adult speech, and investigates a novel joint model of detection and enhancement integrating longitudinal adaptation techniques. The research activities are supported by a new collection of speech data, consisting of stories read in a noisy science museum environment. The recorded dataset will facilitate comparative work in reading assessment and will be released as part of the Ohio Child Speech Corpus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Young students who have difficulty in reading fluently can gain confidence by repeatedly reading story passages.  Computer reading assessment can help improve a student’s fluency while freeing up teachers to help students more efficiently. This project examines a new approach to tracking word-by-word when children read out loud: many previous approaches utilize a speech-to-text system to roughly transcribe what children are saying and matching against the text.  The approach taken in this project is developing a reading verification system that better matches speech against text, accounting for the long pauses and skips that can occur when young readers try to tackle reading passages above their reading level.

The technical outcomes include several pieces of experimental software that track reading progress and identify mistakes in reading.  Over the course of the project, tracking improved from 40 to 73% in the most difficult reading set – a collection of first and second graders with documented reading difficulties – but this also indicates the continuing challenge of handling the speech of these young speakers who are often hesitant and quiet.  Along the way, several other pieces of software were developed, including software to reduce background noise in speech (necessary in classroom settings), a state-of-the-art word aligner for children’s speech, and a web interface for reading assessment.  These outcomes have also resulted in a series of publications at top speech processing conferences (ICASSP and Interspeech), where the findings were disseminated to other research and industry colleagues working in reading assessment.

In addition to the primary technical objectives, one important contribution of this project was the development of the Ohio Children’s Speech Corpus, co-funded with the Ohio Department of Higher Education.  This corpus represents a collection of speech data from 303 children who visited the Center of Science and Industry (COSI) science museum in Columbus, Ohio, and provides recordings and transcriptions for interactions in a variety of tasks, including passage reading and interaction with a social robot.  The data have been released through NSF-funded TalkBank.

In terms of broader impacts, the project advances the state of the art in reading verification, important for impacts in early childhood education technology, as well as providing data and software for other researchers to use.  Moreover, the interactions with both children and families within the Language Sciences Research Lab, a working lab embedded inside the COSI science museum, provided museum visitors with contact to research in language science and language technology in a fun and accessible way.  Finally, the funding for this project provided research opportunities to five graduate students and nine undergraduate students, including eleven female students, one underrepresented student, and one student with a documented disability.
